Vehicle loads dropping, sifting, leaking - see TRAF.
339.08
Littering - see GEN. OFF.
521.08
 
721.01  PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall collect, contract for the collection of or dispose of any
garbage, rubbish or other wastes within the Village, unless such person has
first applied for and received a permit from the Fiscal Officer.
(Ord. 583.  Passed 4-16-53.)
721.02  REGULATIONS.
   The holder of a permit required by Section
721.01 shall be regulated by the health law of the State, and ordinances of the
Village pertaining to the storing and transporting of garbage or other refuse,
within the Village.
(Ord. 583.  Passed 4-16-53.)
721.03  SERVICE MANDATORY.
   The holder of a permit required by Section
721.01 shall not refuse service to any customer, provided the customer complies
with the rules and regulations referred to in this chapter.
(Ord. 583.  Passed 4-16-53.)
721.04  DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE.
   If a customer does not pay within thirty days from the rendering of a bill,
the holder of a permit required by Section
721.01 shall have the right to discontinue the service, and shall notify the
Village of such discontinuance in order to protect the health and welfare of
the residents of the Village.  (Ord. 583.  Passed 4-16-53.)
721.05  PERMIT FEE.
   The fee for the permit required by Section
721.01 is twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
721.06  REVOCATION OF PERMIT.
   A permit issued pursuant to the terms of this chapter can be revoked for
just cause by Council upon a proper hearing.
(Ord. 583.  Passed 4-16-53.)
721.07  GARBAGE AND RUBBISH CONTAINERS REQUIRED.
   (a)   All garbage, rubbish, or other waste within the Village, at all times,
shall be placed in air-tight containers, equipped with a close-fitting
removable cover.  Containers shall be supplied by occupants of the premises and
of sufficient capacity to meet the requirements and needs of the occupants.
   (b)   Containers shall at all times be kept on the premises of the
occupant.  The containers may be placed at a location convenient and accessible
to the collector at 6:00 p.m. or thereafter on the day prior to collection and
shall be removed and placed back on the premises of the occupant by 6:00 p.m.
on the day of collection, and placed in a location, when possible, where said
containers cannot be viewed from the street or sidewalk.
(Ord. 2015-22.  Passed 5-27-15.)
721.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Any person found to be soliciting for transporting, collecting or
disposing of garbage, rubbish or other refuse within the Village, for gain in
violation of the terms of this chapter shall be fined not more than one hundred
dollars ($100.00) or imprisoned not more than thirty days, or both.
(Ord. 583.  Passed 4-16-53.)
   (b)   Any person found violating Section
721.07 shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).  Each
successive day of the violation constitutes a separate offense.
(Ord. 2006-8.  Passed 4-12-06.)
CHAPTER 741
Mechanical Amusement Devices
741.01   Definitions.
741.02   Exhibitor's or amusement arcade license.
741.03   Amusement device license.
741.04   License fees.
741.05   Owner considered exhibitor.
741.06   License procedure.
741.07   Transfer of license or location.
741.08   Fiscal Officer's powers; moral character affidavit.
741.09   Revocation or denial of license; hearing.
741.10   Appeals; Board of Control.
741.11   Minors using devices.
741.12   Seizure of gambling devices.
741.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Gambling devices - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
517
Making or using slugs - see GEN. OFF.
545.11
Tampering with coin machines - see GEN. OFF.
545.12
Mechanical musical devices - see BUS. REG. Ch.
751
 
741.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    "Mechanical or electrical amusement device" means any mechanical or
electrical amusement instrument which, upon the insertion of a coin or slug,
operates or may be operated for the use of a game, contest or any amusement of
any description; which may be used for any such game, contest or amusement;
which contains no automatic pay-off device for the return of slugs, money,
coin, checks, tokens, merchandise or any thing of value; or which contains no
automatic device by the operation of which the player may win at uncertain
intervals a free game, a free play or any other additional amusement. This
definition does not include any mechanically or electrically operated amusement
instrument which is a gambling device as such. This definition does not include
merchandise vending machines. A juke box shall not be considered as a
"mechanical or electrical amusement device".
   (b)    "Amusement arcade" means a place of amusement which derives in excess
of seventy percent (70%) of its gross receipts from the operation of
mechanically or electrically operated amusement devices or which has five or
more mechanical or electric devices. However, in the case of any person
operating a carnival which contains an amusement arcade as a part of it, the
seventy percent (70%) gross receipts referred to above shall apply only to the
gross receipts of the amusement arcade and not to the gross receipts for the
operation of the entire carnival. An "amusement arcade" shall have a closing
time of 10:30 p.m. each evening.
(Ord. 81-45. Passed 12-9-81.)
   (c)    "Owner" means any person actually owning and having title to any
mechanical or electrical amusement device, who receives all or any of the
profit from the use and exhibition of such device installed, used and exhibited
by such person in his own place of business.
   (d)    "Exhibitor" means any person contracting for or permitting any
mechanical or electrical amusement device to be installed, used and exhibited
in other than his own place of business. (Ord.  480. Passed 12-19-46.)
741.02  EXHIBITOR'S OR AMUSEMENT ARCADE LICENSE.
   No exhibitor shall install or permit the use of any mechanical or electrical
amusement device, and no owner or other person shall operate an amusement
arcade without first obtaining an exhibitor's or amusement arcade license from
the Village Fiscal Officer. The Fiscal Officer shall not issue a license to any
exhibitor who installs or proposes to install any gambling device as such. The
Fiscal Officer may not issue a license for any device that is adopted to or may
be readily converted into a gambling device. The license shall be issued only
to persons of good moral character and shall not be transferable to any other
person, except as provided in Section 741.07. (Ord.  480. Passed 12-19-46.)
741.03  AMUSEMENT DEVICE LICENSE.
   Each mechanical or electrical amusement device, shall be licensed, and no
person shall keep, maintain, permit or allow any unlicensed device to be in or
upon any public place of business under the control, supervision or direction
of such person other than a person exempt from the licensing provisions of this
chapter. Each amusement arcade shall be licensed as an amusement arcade and a
license therefor shall be required in addition to and independent of, the
license required for each mechanical or electrical amusement device.
(Ord. 480. Passed 12-19-46.)
741.04  LICENSE FEES.
   (a)    The Village Fiscal Officer is hereby authorized to issue licenses to
exhibitors of mechanical or electrical amusement devices and to issue licenses
to owners or other persons, operating amusement arcades upon payment of the
following fees:
      (1)    For "mechanical or electrical amusement devices": twenty-five
dollars ($25.00) per year for each machine.
      (2)    For a juke box: twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per year for each
machine.
      (3)    For amusement arcades: one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year for
each place of business, or seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for any period of one
hundred and eighty-two days or less falling within anyone calendar year.
   Such fee shall be in addition to and independent of a machine or exhibitors'
fee.
   (b)    No licenses shall be issued to an applicant until the Fiscal Officer
has found that the applicant is of good moral character. The lack of finding of
good moral character on the part of the applicant shall be grounds for denial
or revocation of such licenses by the Clerk.
(Ord. 81-45. Passed 12-9-81.)
741.05  OWNER CONSIDERED EXHIBITOR.
   An owner, who actually owns and who also installs, uses and exhibits any
mechanical or electrical amusement device in his own place of business, is
deemed to be an exhibitor and is required to take out a machine license for
each mechanical or electrical amusement device used. However, any owner who
owns and also installs, uses or exhibits any mechanical or electrical amusement
device in his own place of business shall file an affidavit with the Fiscal
Officer setting forth that he is the bona fide owner of such mechanical or
electrical amusement device and that as such owner, he receives some benefits
from the operation of it and that no other person has any actual or beneficial
interest therein, either directly or indirectly.
(Ord. 480. Passed 12-19-46.)
741.06  LICENSE PROCEDURE.
   Every applicant for an exhibitor's license shall file an affidavit with the
Village Fiscal Officer prior to receiving such license listing the number of
machines intending to be exhibited together with an affidavit as to good moral
character required for a license by Section
741.04. Upon payment of the fee required by this chapter, the Village Fiscal
Officer shall issue a license which shall contain the name and address of the
licensee, the number of the mechanical or electrical amusement devices
exhibited, or amusement arcades intending to be operated, and the serial number
of the license. A licensee, desiring to exhibit additional mechanical or
electrical amusement devices or operate additional amusement arcades during the
license period, shall apply for a license to cover the exhibition of such
additional mechanical or electrical amusement devices or the operation of such
additional amusement arcades in the manner above set forth and shall pay the
fee or fees required by this chapter for the exhibition of any such additional
mechanical or electrical amusement devices or the operation of any additional
amusement arcades. The type of individual licenses to be issued and their
manner of display, shall be prescribed by rules and regulations established and
adopted by the Fiscal Officer. All licenses for one year shall expire on
December 31 of each year, unless earlier revoked by the Fiscal Officer. All
amusement arcade licenses issued for one hundred eighty- two days or less shall
expire at the close of business on the one hundred eighty-second day after
issuance unless earlier revoked by the Fiscal Officer. No license fee shall be
charged for mechanical or electrical amusement devices operated solely or
directly for the benefit of a charitable, benevolent or religious institution.
(Ord. 480. Passed 12-19-46.)
741.07  TRANSFER OF LICENSE OR LOCATION.
   The Village Fiscal Officer is hereby authorized to permit the transfer of a
license from one mechanical amusement device to another, or from one location
of an amusement arcade to another location, if there is a change of location
only, and not a change of ownership or operation of such amusement arcade. Such
permit to transfer shall be made under the conditions prescribed by rules and
regulations established and adopted by the Fiscal Officer.
(Ord. 480. Passed 12-19-46.)
741.08  FISCAL OFFICER'S POWERS; MORAL CHARACTER AFFIDAVIT.
   The Village Fiscal Officer is hereby empowered to establish and enforce or
cause to be enforced such rules and regulations governing the issuance of the
licenses required in this chapter as he believes reasonable and necessary and
not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter. Applicants for licenses
required by Section
741.02 shall be of good moral character and the Fiscal Officer shall adopt and
enforce a regulation requiring an affidavit by such applicant relative to any
arrest or conviction of the applicant for any crime involving moral turpitude
within a period of five years immediately preceding the date of application.
(Ord. 480. Passed 12-19-46.)
741.09  REVOCATION OR DENIAL OF LICENSE; HEARING.
   The license of any person, violating any of the provisions of this chapter
or any of the rules and regulations established and adopted by the Village
Fiscal Officer as provided for by Section
741.08 shall be revoked by the Fiscal Officer. The Fiscal Officer is also
hereby authorized to deny, for reasonable cause, an application for a license.
The Fiscal Officer shall notify such licensee of any hearing of the Fiscal
Officer involving the denial or revocation of such license. Such notification
shall be sent by registered mail to the last address of the licensee on file
with the Fiscal Officer.
(Ord. 480. Passed 12-19-46.)
741.10  APPEALS; BOARD OF CONTROL.
   An applicant who has been refused a license or a licensee whose license has
been revoked may appeal in writing to the Board of Control, within ten days
after the date of the mailing of the notice of the denial or revocation of a
license. The Board of Control shall consider such appeal within five days after
the date the written appeal is filed with the Board. The Board may, in its
discretion, consider such appeal either solely upon the evidence considered by
the Village Fiscal Officer or by permitting new evidence to be offered. Upon
such hearing, the Board of Control shall affirm, disaffirm or modify such order
or denial or revocation from which the appeal has been taken.
   The written appeal shall be filed with the Mayor as the Chairman of the
Board of Control.
   The Board of Control shall be composed of the Mayor, and the Fiscal Officer.
(Ord. 480. Passed 12-19-46.)
741.11  MINORS USING DEVICES.
   No person shall permit any mechanical or electrical amusement device to be
played by any minor under the age of fifteen years unless such minor is
accompanied by a parent, guardian, or other adult relative.
(Ord. 480. Passed 12-19-46.)
741.12  SEIZURE OF GAMBLING DEVICES.
   Any machine, apparatus, contrivance or device which is changed to or may be
readily converted into a gambling device which is exhibited or made use of by
any owner or exhibitor, in violation of the terms of this chapter, may be
seized and destroyed in compliance with the terms and provisions of the
statutes of the State, regulating gambling devices.
(Ord. 480. Passed 12-19-46.)
741.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever owns or operates any mechanical or electrical amusement device or
operates an amusement arcade without first obtaining a license and paying the
fee required for it or who exhibits or operates such a machine, device or
amusement arcade or permits the same to be exhibited or operated for gambling
or otherwise violates any provision of this chapter or any rule or regulation
established by the Fiscal Officer pursuant to Section
741.08 shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisoned
not more than ninety days, or both. In addition, such licensee may have his
license revoked.  Whoever swears falsely in an affidavit required to be made
under the terms of this chapter, shall be guilty of perjury and shall be
subject to the penalty provided by State statute.
(Ord. 480. Passed 12-19-46.)
CHAPTER 751
Mechanical Musical Devices
751.01   Definition.
751.02   License required.
751.03   License application.
751.04   License fees and registration.
751.05   Application for transfer of registration sticker.
751.06   Records.
751.07   Use regulations.
751.08   Powers of Village Fiscal Officer.
751.09   Revocation or denial of license.
751.10   Appeals; Board of Control.
751.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Disturbing the peace - see GEN. OFF.
509.03
Mechanical amusement devices - see BUS. REG. Ch.
741
 
751.01  DEFINITIONS.
   "Mechanical musical device" as used in this chapter means and includes any
amusement machine or apparatus designed or constructed for the purpose of
producing, reproducing or playing any musical or vocal tone or tones or
combination of tones, the operation or use of which is permitted, controlled,
allowed or made possible by the deposit or placing of any coin, plate, disc,
token or key into any slot, crevice or other opening in such instrument.
(Ord. 479. Passed 12-19-46.)
751.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   A license is required for the operation of a mechanical musical device and
no person shall maintain, operate or permit to be maintained or operated, in,
upon or about any premises under his control, which are open to the public, any
mechanical musical device unless a license for it has been obtained from the
Fiscal Officer of the Village. Premises which are open to the public include
clubs, private clubs, headquarters and meeting places of fraternal and other
societies, associations and bodies and all other public places.
(Ord. 479. Passed 12-19-46.)
751.03  LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Application for a license for a mechanical musical device shall be made to
the Fiscal Officer of the Village upon such forms as are prescribed therefor.
The applicant shall state his or its name; whether an individual, partnership
or corporation; if a partnership, the names and addresses of the partners
composing the same; the addresses at which it is desired to maintain and
operate the mechanical musical device; the nature of the business conducted, at
that address; the make, name, model serial number and other identifying
information with reference to the particular mechanical musical device which
the applicant desires to be licensed; the name and address of the owner of such
device and such further information as the Fiscal Officer, in his discretion
may require.
(Ord. 479. Passed 12-19-46.)
751.04  LICENSE FEES AND REGISTRATION STICKER.
   Upon the filing of an application and the payment of ten dollars ($10.00),
the Fiscal Officer of the Village shall issue to the applicant a license which
shall entitle the licensee to maintain and operate at the premises mentioned in
the application, the mechanical musical device described in the application,
subject to the terms and conditions of this chapter, any other ordinances of
the Village, and subject to the rules which may be hereinafter set forth by the
Village Fiscal Officer. At the time of the issuance of the license, the Fiscal
Officer shall also issue to the licensee a registration slip or sticker for
each mechanical musical device described in the application. The license fee
provided above, shall be the annual license fee for the fiscal year which shall
expire December 31, of each calendar year. However, for any license issued
after July 1 in any calendar year the license fee for the balance of the
calendar year shall be five dollars ($5.00).
(Ord. 479. Passed 12-19-46.)
751.05  APPLICATION FOR TRANSFER OF REGISTRATION STICKER.
   Any licensee of a mechanical musical device may transfer the registration
sticker from one device to another if the application for such transfer is made
to, and approved by the Fiscal Officer of the Village, prior to the making of
such transfer and a record of it made in his office. There shall be no fee for
the transfer.
(Ord. 479. Passed 12-19-46.)
751.06  RECORDS.
   The Fiscal Officer of the Village, shall keep and maintain on file in his
office a full and complete list of all licenses granted under this chapter, and
also a full and complete list of all mechanical musical devices which are
registered under this chapter, together with a cross index showing the location
of the registered mechanical musical devices.
(Ord. 479. Passed 12-19-46.)
751.07  USE REGULATIONS.
   No person shall play, produce or reproduce upon any mechanical musical
device any obscene selection or rendition. No person shall use, permit to be
used, or maintain any mechanical musical device in such manner as to disturb
the peace and quiet of the neighborhood in which it is used.
(Ord. 479. Passed 12-19-46.)
751.08  POWERS OF VILLAGE FISCAL OFFICER.
   The Village Fiscal Officer is hereby authorized and empowered to establish,
adopt and enforce or cause to be enforced such rules and regulations governing
the issuance of licenses required in this chapter as he may believe reasonable
and necessary and not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 479. Passed 12-19-46.)
751.09  REVOCATION OR DENIAL OF LICENSE.
   The license of any person who violates any of the terms of this chapter or
any of the rules and regulations established by the Village Fiscal Officer
shall be revoked by the Fiscal Officer. The Fiscal Officer is hereby authorized
to deny an application for license for any reasonable cause. The Fiscal Officer
shall notify such licensee of any hearing involving the denial or revocation of
such license. The notification shall be sent by registered mail to the last
address of the licensee on file with the Fiscal Officer.  (Ord. 479. Passed 12-
19-46.)
751.10  APPEALS; BOARD OF CONTROL.
   Any person who has been refused a license, or licensee whose license has
been revoked, may appeal in writing to the Board of Control of the Village
within ten days after the date of mailing of the notice of denial or
revocation. The Board of Control may consider such appeal in whatever manner it
may believe proper.
   The Board of Control shall be composed of the Mayor, and the Fiscal Officer.
(Ord. 479. Passed 12-19-46.)
751.99  PENALTY.
   Any person who maintains or operates any mechanical musical device in any
public place without first having obtained a license for it shall be fined not
more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). Any person or licensee who violates
any of the provisions of this chapter, or any rules of the Village Fiscal
Officer established and adopted hereunder, may have his license revoked and in
addition thereto be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 479. Passed 12-19-46.)
CHAPTER 771
Peddlers and Solicitors
771.01   Permit required.
771.02   Fees; duration.
771.03   Hours.
771.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to inspect food products - see Ohio R.C. 715.46
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61 et seq.
Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1716
Use of stands on sidewalks prohibited - see Ohio R.C. 2923.22
Frozen desserts - see Ohio R.C. 3717.51 et seq.
Littering - see Ohio R.C. 3767.20
Sales of goods and services within right of way of interstate and other state
highways - see Ohio R.C. 5515.07
Retail sales license - see Ohio R.C. 5739.17
Trespassing - see GEN. OFF.
541.05
 
771.01  PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Every person wanting to engage in the business of traveling within the
Village, soliciting orders for or selling goods, wares, merchandise or other
articles for profit, and every person wanting to engage in the solicitation of
funds for any charitable, religious, educational or other purpose, is required
first to apply for and obtain a permit to engage in such activity from the
Fiscal Officer.  The permit shall be for a stated length of time and shall
require the advance payment of the fees set forth under Section
771.02.
(Ord. 2005-11.  Passed 5-25-05.)
771.02  FEES; DURATION.
   (a)   The permits required by Section
771.01 shall be for the periods of time and require the advance payment of the
fees as follows:
      (1)   For any length of time up to, and including, ten days: twenty-five
dollars ($25.00);
      (2)   For any length of time in excess of ten days, but not in excess of
thirty days: seventy-five dollars ($75.00).
   No permit shall be issued for any period of time in excess of thirty days
from the effective date of the permit.  If an applicant desires to continue in
an activity herein regulated for a period of time longer than thirty days, he
must reapply for a new permit and pay the fee  required for it by this Section,
upon the expiration of the time for which the initial permit was issued.
      (3)   No fee shall be charged for a permit issued to a civic and/or non-
profit group.
   (b)   A permit issued to a civic and/or non-profit group shall be effective
for a period of time not to exceed one year from the effective date of the
permit.
(Ord. 2005-11.  Passed 5-25-05.)
771.03  HOURS.
   (a)   Solicitations by civic and/or non-profit organizations shall be
conducted from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday through Sunday.
   (b)   All other peddlers and solicitors shall be permitted to conduct
activities within the Village during week days from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.
   (c)   All persons conducting solicitations upon municipal streets, state
routes or other roads located within the corporate limits of the Village shall
wear a safety vest of either reflective or non-reflective material.  The vest
will be supplied by the group or individual conducting the solicitation.  All
persons soliciting donations must wear identification identifying the person or
organization when soliciting.
(Ord. 2005-11.  Passed 5-25-05.)
771.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this Chapter shall be fined twenty-five
dollars ($25.00).  Each day during which a violation continues shall constitute
a separate and distinct offense.  In addition, the solicitation permit of any
person or group violating this Section may be revoked at any time for behavior
deemed inappropriate including, but not limited to, fraud, misrepresentation,
inappropriate sales activities, intoxication, or other similar violation.
(Ord. 2005-11.  Passed 5-25-05.)
CHAPTER 781
Taxicabs
781.01   Definitions.
781.02   License and fees required.
781.03   Application information.
781.04   Initial issuance and renewal; maximum number.
781.05   License transfer; taxicab sale.
781.06   Revocation for nonuse.
781.07   Liability insurance required.
781.08   Limits of liability insurance.
781.09   Insurance cancellation  reinstatement and fee. 
781.10   Revocation for nonpayment  of judgement.
781.11   Taxicab driver's license;  application information.
781.12   Prohibited acts; overcharging.
781.13   Charges. (Repealed)
781.14   Baggage charges. (Repealed)
781.15   Articles left in vehicle.
781.16   Passenger carriage limited to taxicabs and busses.
781.17   Failure to pay fare; evidence.
781.18   Exhibition of rate charts in taxicabs.
781.19   Vehicle equipment and inspections.
781.20   Immoral use of vehicle.
781.21   Carrying capacity limited.
781.22   Operation without taxicab license.
781.23   Driving with license suspended; revocation.
781.24   Driving while intoxicated;  revocation.
781.25   Smoking prohibited.
781.26   Fiscal Officer may make regulations; continuing jurisdiction.
781.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.22, 715.66
Power to establish stands and fix rates - see Ohio R.C. 715.25
Operation and equipment - see TRAF. CODE
 
781.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    "Taxicab" means and includes all motor-driven vehicles carrying
passengers for hire on the streets of the Village, except motor busses operated
on regular schedules and over regularly established routes. Wherever the word
"cab" is used in this chapter, it shall be construed to mean a taxicab.
   (b)    "Fiscal Officer" means the Fiscal Officer of the Village or his
successor.
   (c)    "Taxicab owner" or "operator" means and includes every corporation,
association, joint stock association, person, firm or copartnership, and their
lessees, directors, receivers or trustees appointed by any court whatsoever, or
the heirs, executors, administrators, personal representatives or assigns of
any deceased owner, owning, controlling, operating or managing any taxicab.
   (d)    "Taxicab driver" or "driver", means the person driving a taxicab.
   (e)    "Public convenience and necessity", means a genuine need for
additional taxicab transportation facilities in order to adequately and
properly serve the needs and conveniences of the general public of the Village.
(Ord. 838. Passed 7-10-72.)
781.02  LICENSE AND FEES REQUIRED.
   No taxicab shall be operated within the corporate limits of the Village,
unless a license has been issued to the owner thereof and is in force. Every
license shall expire on December 31 of the year in which it is issued.
(Ord. 838. Passed 7-10-72.)
781.03  APPLICATION INFORMATION.
   Applications for licenses for taxicabs shall be made to the Fiscal Officer,
upon blanks provided by the Fiscal Officer, and shall set forth the name and
address of the applicant, the trade name under which he does business, the
class of vehicle for which the license is desired, the seating capacity, design
and color scheme of such vehicle for which the license is desired and any other
information as may be required by the Fiscal Officer. If the application is
granted, the applicant shall furnish the Fiscal Officer, prior to the issuance
of the license, with information covering the particular vehicle to be
licensed. Such information shall include the make, the State license number,
the length of time the vehicle has been in use, the motor number and the name
and address of the person, firm or corporation from which the vehicle was
purchased, together with a copy of the bill of sale and any other information
required by the Fiscal Officer.
(Ord. 838. Passed 7-10-72.)
   (b)   The fee for applications for licenses for taxi cabs shall be fifty
dollars ($50.00) and shall be paid to the Fiscal Officer at the time the
application is filed. 
(Ord. 2011-10.  Passed 5-25-11.)
781.04  INITIAL ISSUANCE AND RENEWAL; MAXIMUM NUMBER.
   (a)    The Fiscal Officer shall investigate each application for a taxicab
license, and if he decides after such investigation, that the public
convenience and necessity justify the operation of the vehicle for which the
license is desired, the applicant shall furnish the Fiscal Officer with any
additional information required. If the Fiscal Officer then finds that the
applicant is the owner of the vehicle for which the license is desired, that
the vehicle is a safe and fit conveyance and that it complies with all the
requirements of this chapter, he shall issue a license to the applicant upon
the furnishing of the bond or insurance required.
   (b)    All taxicab licenses, in accordance with the terms of this chapter,
shall have their licenses renewed for each succeeding year without a finding of
convenience and necessity of the Fiscal Officer, providing all other
requirements of this chapter are complied with.
(Ord. 838. Passed 7-10-72; Ord. 2011-10.  Passed 5-25-11.)
781.05  LICENSE TRANSFER; TAXICAB SALE.
   (a)    No taxicab license shall be transferred from one owner to another
except after a finding of public convenience and necessity by the Fiscal
Officer. The applicant for the transfer of the license shall file with his
application the consent, in writing, of the former owner of such license and
shall comply with all the terms and conditions of all Village ordinances
concerning taxicabs.
   (b)    Every owner of a licensed taxicab shall notify the Fiscal Officer
upon the sale of any licensed taxicab when it is intended that the purchaser
continues to operate it as a taxicab within the Village.
(Ord. 838. Passed 7-10-72.)
781.06  REVOCATION FOR NONUSE.
   Whenever any person holding a license for a taxicab fails, for a period of
sixty consecutive days, to make a reasonable and consistent effort to operate
any such licensed taxicab, the Fiscal Officer shall revoke the license for such
taxicab.
(Ord. 838. Passed 7-10-72.)
781.07  LIABILITY INSURANCE REQUIRED.
   No license to operate any taxicab shall be issued or renewed by the Fiscal
Officer, and no person shall operate or permit the operation of any such
taxicab unless and until the owner of the same deposits and maintains on
deposit with the Fiscal Officer, a policy of an insurance company duly licensed
to transact such business in this State. Such policy, within the amounts
specified in Section
781.08, shall insure the owner of such taxicab and also any operator operating
the same in the Village as a taxicab under the authority of the owner, whether
such authority is under contract of employment, lease or other transaction of
the owner or the owner's assignee or lessee. Such policy shall also insure the
driver of such taxicab, against loss from the liability imposed by law for
damages on account of bodily injuries or death and/or for damage to property,
other than injuries, death or property damage of the insured or insured's
employees, resulting from such ownership, maintenance or use of such taxicab in
the Village, and agreeing to pay to any judgement creditor, to the extent of
the respective amounts specified in such policy, and final judgement rendered
against the assured or such operator by reason of such liability.  (Ord. 838.
Passed 7-10-72.)
781.08  LIMITS OF LIABILITY INSURANCE.
   (a)   The limit, in any such insurance policy, of liability of the insurer
on account of the ownership, maintenance and use of each such taxicab shall be
not less than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000) for bodily injuries to or
death of one person, and subject to such limit as to injury or death of one
person; fifty thousand dollars ($50,000) on account of any one accident
resulting in injuries to and/or death of more than one person; and twenty
thousand dollars ($20,000) on account of damage to property in any one
accident.
 
   (b)   Any such insurance policy shall be subject to the approval of the
Village Solicitor as to its form and compliance with this Chapter.
(Ord. 2011-10.  Passed 5-25-11.)
781.09  INSURANCE CANCELLATION; REINSTATEMENT AND FEE.
   Such insurance policy may provide for cancellation by the insurer upon
written notice to the Fiscal Officer, but this provision shall not be construed
to waive any lawful notice which the insurer must give to the insured. Upon
cancellation the license covered by the policy shall be revoked by the Fiscal
Officer. In case a license is revoked, the Fiscal Officer may, upon the filing
of a new policy of insurance and its approval by the Village Solicitor,
reinstate the license, provided this is done within ten days from revocation
and a fee of five dollars ($5.00) is paid for such reinstatement.  (Ord. 838.
Passed 7-10-72.)
781.10  REVOCATION FOR NONPAYMENT OF JUDGMENT.
   In the event of any final judgment against the owner of any taxicab for
damages on account of bodily injuries, or death and/or for damage to property,
other than injuries, death or property damage of the owner or owner's
employees, resulting from such ownership, maintenance or use of the taxicab in
the Village, and the nonpayment thereof for a period of thirty days thereafter,
the Fiscal Officer shall forthwith revoke all licenses of all taxicabs of the
owner in the manner provided in the preceding section.
(Ord. 838. Passed 7-10-72.)
781.11  TAXICAB DRIVER'S LICENSE; APPLICATION INFORMATION.
   No person shall drive or operate a taxicab unless he is licensed as required
by Ohio R.C. Chapter 4507.
(Ord. 838. Passed 7-10-72.)
781.12  PROHIBITED ACTS; OVERCHARGING.
   (a)    No owner of any taxicab within the Village shall operate his taxicab
to pickup passengers at another stand other than the one operated as his own,
unless instructed to do so by the operator of the other stand.
   (b)    Any taxicab owner who refuses to pickup any passenger, regardless of
distance, within the Village limits, except on alleys or streets that are
impassable for travel, shall upon proof and conviction of such act, have his
operator's license revoked and shall not be permitted to secure another license
for a period of ninety days after such license is revoked.
   (c)    Any driver who overcharges a passenger within the limits of the
Village shall be suspended for a period of thirty days for the first offense
and discharged from service on a second offense of like nature.
   (d)    Any driver or owner of a taxicab found guilty of soliciting
passengers in front of another taxicab stand, shall for a first offense be
given a citation and hearing. For the second offense, the driver's license
shall be revoked, and the owner of the taxicab shall, if he has full knowledge
of the offense, be given a citation and hearing before the Municipal Court, and
on conviction he shall have his license revoked.
   (e)    Any driver who is found guilty of transporting intoxicating liquors
in his taxicab with or without knowledge of the owner shall be discharged. If
the owner has knowledge and permits such intoxicating liquors to be
transported, he shall upon conviction, be compelled to surrender his license to
operate a taxicab within the Village.
(Ord. 838. Passed 7-10-72.)
781.13  CHARGES. (REPEALED)
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
781.13 was repealed by Ordinance 2011-10.
781.14  BAGGAGE CHARGES. (REPEALED)
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
781.14 was repealed by Ordinance 2011-10.
781.15  ARTICLES LEFT IN VEHICLE.
   Drivers of taxicabs shall promptly deliver to the Guernsey County Sheriff’s
Department, or to authorized agencies of their companies, all property of value
left in the vehicle by passengers. 
(Ord. 2011-10.  Passed 5-25-11.)
781.16  PASSENGER CARRIAGE LIMITED TO TAXICABS AND BUSSES.
   The carrying of passengers as a business for compensation by any vehicle
other than a taxicab, duly licensed under and operating in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter, or by motorbuses, operating under proper authority,
is hereby prohibited.
(Ord. 838. Passed 7-10-72.)
781.17  FAILURE TO PAY FARE; EVIDENCE.
   No person shall with intent to defraud the owner or driver of any taxicab,
engage carriage therein. Refusal to pay the lawful charge for such carriage, or
absconding without payment or offer to pay, shall be evidence of such intent to
defraud.
(Ord. 838. Passed 7-10-72.)
781.18  EXHIBITION OF RATE CHARTS IN TAXICABS.
   There shall be exhibited in each taxicab, while it is in operation, a rate
chart setting forth the rates, charges or fees prescribed in this chapter. Such
rate chart shall be placed in a conspicuous place in the taxicab where it is
plainly visible to taxicab patrons at all times.
(Ord. 838. Passed 7-10-72.)
781.19  VEHICLE EQUIPMENT AND INSPECTIONS.
   (a)    Every taxicab shall be kept in a safe and sanitary operating
condition and shall at all times have the following equipment:
      (1)    A light, within the passenger compartment, capable of being
lighted and extinguished by the passenger;
      (2)    A spare tire capable of being used on any of the wheels of the
vehicle;
      (3)    A set of tools for changing tires;
      (4)    An efficient braking system which will be capable of stopping the
vehicle without load in a distance of twenty-two feet when operating on a
level, dry, asphalt street at a speed of twenty miles per hour; and
      (5)    Skid chains to be applied to the rear wheels when road or weather
conditions make their use necessary.
   (b)    All outside lights, other than the usual headlights or parking
lights, are to be placed on the top of the taxicab to provide adequate
identification at night.
   (c)    All taxicabs must be inspected three times a year at four month
intervals by a person approved and designated by the Fiscal Officer, and who is
to file with the Fiscal Officer a copy of such inspection reports. All
recommendations are to be complied with by the owner of the taxicab within a
reasonable time, which shall be no later than thirty days from the date of
notification.
   (d)    Any taxicab company using radios shall use a single channel set. If
multi-channel sets are owned, all other channels shall be removed from the set
other than the channel number issued and authorized.
(Ord. 838. Passed 7-10-72.)
781.20  IMMORAL USE OF VEHICLE.
   (a)    No person shall use a taxicab for any unlawful or immoral purpose.
   (b)    Upon information that such unlawful or immoral use has occurred with
the knowledge of the person owning the taxicab, the Fiscal Officer shall revoke
the vehicle license for the vehicle involved.
(Ord. 838. Passed 7-10-72.)
781.21  CARRYING CAPACITY LIMITED.
   No taxicab shall carry more passengers than the number designated as its
seating capacity in the application on which the license was issued.
(Ord. 838. Passed 7-10-72.)
781.22  OPERATION WITHOUT TAXICAB LICENSE.
   No person shall operate or permit to be operated for hire an unlicensed
vehicle. In the event of conviction, in addition to any other penalty imposed,
such person shall not thereafter be granted a license for the vehicle concerned
for a period of three months for a first conviction and one year for a
subsequent conviction.
781.23  DRIVING WITH LICENSE SUSPENDED; REVOCATION.
   Whenever a licensed driver is convicted of driving a taxicab, for which a
driver's license is required, during a period for which his license has been
suspended, it shall be mandatory upon the Fiscal Officer to revoke the license
of such driver. Such driver shall not be eligible to receive a new license for
a period of one year from the date of such revocation.
(Ord. 838.  Passed 7-10-72.)
781.24  DRIVING WHILE INTOXICATED; REVOCATION.
   Conviction of driving while intoxicated shall operate as a revocation of any
driver's license issued hereunder. Such driver shall not be eligible to receive
a new license for a period of one year from the date of such conviction.
(Ord. 838. Passed 7-10-72.)
781.25  SMOKING PROHIBITED.
   Drivers of taxicabs are prohibited from smoking while carrying passengers.
(Ord. 838. Passed 7-10-72.)
781.26  FISCAL OFFICER MAY MAKE REGULATIONS; CONTINUING JURISDICTION.
   (a)    The Fiscal Officer is hereby authorized and empowered to establish
and adopt such additional rules and regulations governing the issuance of
licenses to drive taxicabs as may be reasonable and necessary and which are not
inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter.
   (b)    The Fiscal Officer shall have continuing jurisdiction as to licenses
granted hereunder. In the event of misconduct or acts on the part of a licensed
driver which show him to be an unsuitable person to drive a taxicab, or which
would be sufficient to justify the refusal of a license in the case of an
original applicant, the Fiscal Officer shall revoke a license already granted.
(Ord. 838. Passed 7-10-72.)
781.99  PENALTY.
   In addition to license revocation or any other penalty that may be
specifically provided for herein, whoever violates any provision of this
chapter shall be fined not more than one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00).
Any such violation shall constitute a separate offense on each successive day
continued. 
(Ord. 2011-10.  Passed 5-25-11.)
CHAPTER 791
Yard Sales
791.01   Definitions.
791.02   Maximum number of sales.
791.03   Sale hours.
791.04   Merchandise restriction.
791.05   Sign restrictions.
791.06   Exceptions.
791.07   Complaints.
791.08   Injunctive relief.
791.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Secondhand dealers - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4737
Receiving stolen property - see GEN. OFF.
545.18
 
791.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   (a)   “Person”  means individuals, associations of individuals,
partnerships, or corporations who or which conduct sales for a commission or
other remuneration.  “Person” shall include spouse, children, residents of a
household, or other residents or a particular residential premises.
   (b)   “Public sale”  means any sale and delivery or offer of sale and
delivery of any household furniture, furnishings, equipment, farm products,
goods, wares, or merchandise from, in, about, or upon a premises, property, or
residence municipality to which the general public is invited, pursuant to any
advertisement or notice by newspaper, radio, mail, individual flier, exterior
graphics, or similar modes or advertising.  Excluded from this definition are
sales conducted by estate fiduciaries and licensed auctioneers.
   (c)   “Yard sale”  means a sale of household goods, furniture, equipment,
utensils, appliances, tools, personal clothing or effects, novelty items,
glassware, farm products, or similar personal property including, but not
limited to, such sales commonly termed “Porch sales”, “garage sales”, “lawn
sales”,  “group family sale”, “rummage sale” “white elephant sale”, or “attic
sale”.
      (Ord. 99-15.  Passed 10-21-99.)
791.02  MAXIMUM NUMBER OF SALES.
   No person shall conduct, sponsor, hold, manage, or permit upon the premises
he occupies, more than six public sales or yard sales in any twelve month
period, or more than one public sale or yard sale in any one month.  Sales
shall not exceed two days in duration.
(Ord. 99-15.  Passed 10-21-99.)
791.03  SALE HOURS.
   No person shall conduct a public sale or yard sale before 9:00 a.m. of any
day or after 7:00 p.m. of any day.  (Ord. 99-15.  Passed 10-21-99.)
791.04  MERCHANDISE RESTRICTION.
   No person shall sell at any public sale, any household furniture, equipment,
appliances, goods, or food products which were brought onto the property for
the sole purpose of selling the same at the sale by a person who regularly
furnishes the household furniture, furnishings, equipment, appliances, goods,
or food products at the public sale or yard sale for profit, excepting sales
which are conducted by any charitable, educational, or religious institution.
(Ord. 99-15.  Passed 10-21-99.)
791.05  SIGN RESTRICTIONS.
   Signs advertising public sales and yard sales shall not exceed two feet by
two feet in dimension and shall contain the address of the sale sponsor.  All
signs pertaining to these sales shall be removed from display within twenty-
four hours after completion of the sale.  The Building Inspector and/or Police
Department shall be authorized to remove nonconforming or unauthorized signs in
the public right-of-way. 
(Ord. 99-15.  Passed 10-21-99.)
791.06  EXCEPTIONS.
   This chapter shall not apply to any public sale or yard sale conducted
solely by any charitable, educational, or religious institution. (Ord. 99-15. 
Passed 10-21-99.)
791.07  COMPLAINTS.
   Complaints shall be filed in the name of the Village of Byesville or its
designee on behalf of the Village.  The complaint shall be filed and prosecuted
by the Village Solicitor or his assistant.  (Ord. 99-15.  Passed 10-21-99.)
791.08  INJUNCTIVE RELIEF.
   Upon certification by the Building Inspector and/or the Police Department to
the Village Solicitor that a person is engaged in a pattern of practice of
violations of any provision of this chapter, the Village Solicitor, or his
assistant, shall be authorized to seek on behalf of the Village both temporary
and permanent injunctive relief in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. 99-15.  Passed 10-21-99.)
791.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever is found guilty of violating any provision of this chapter shall be
guilty of a minor misdemeanor.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed
upon each day during which the violation occurs or continues.  (Ord. 99-15. 
Passed 10-21-99.)

905.01  DRAINAGE CONSTRUCTION; PERMIT.
   (a)   No person shall construct drainage facilities along a street or alley
of the Village without the written consent of the Street Commissioner, or the
Mayor if the Street Commissioner is not available.
   (b)   The drainage facilities shall be constructed in accordance with
specifications on file in the office of the Fiscal Officer.
(Ord. 640.  Passed 5-21-57.)
905.02  EXCAVATION; PERMIT; BOND; SPECIFICATIONS.
   (a)   No person, firm or corporation shall dig, cut, open, excavate or
trench any public street, alley, right of way or easement of the Village
without a permit therefor and without compliance with the regulations
hereinafter set forth.
(Ord. 917.  Passed 5-8-75.)
   (b)   A permit pursuant to this section shall be issued by the Fiscal
Officer upon the payment of a fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
(Ord. 2007-13.  Passed 8-22-07.)
   (c)   The Fiscal Officer shall establish standard specifications for
restoration of public property, for providing adequate protective devices and
traffic controls, and for general procedures in crossing paved streets.
      (1)   The repair to the street or alley shall be under the supervision of
the Street Superintendent.
      (2)   The repair of streets shall meet one of the following standards:
         A.   Two inches of asphalt (404) shall be placed on top of six inches
of concrete (452), both of which shall be one foot wider on each side than the
pipe trench.  The pipe trench shall be backfilled with compacted dirt at least
six inches above the pipe and granular backfill to the bottom of the concrete. 
Cold-mix may be used temporarily until asphalt is available.
         B.    Eight inches of concrete which shall be one foot wider on each
side than the pipe trench. The pipe trench shall be backfilled with compacted
dirt at least six inches above the pipe and granular backfill to the bottom of
the concrete. Cold-mix may be used temporarily until concrete is available.
      (3)    The repair at alleys shall meet the following standard:
         A.    Two inches of asphalt (404) shall be placed on top of six inches
of mechanically compacted subbase (310). The pipe trench shall be backfilled to
the bottom of the subbase with compacted granular backfill.
      (4)    Should the alley or street be unpaved the compacted dirt shall be
placed at least six inches above the pipe with the balance of the fill to be of
crushed stone.
   (d)    No cuts shall be made in any paved street or alley within three years
after the surfacing thereof, except as specifically authorized by the Fiscal
Officer, providing, however, that at least ninety days prior to the paving or
resurfacing of any street or alley with concrete or asphaltic concrete (404 or
equivalent), a notice shall be mailed to the property owners indicating that
the paving or resurfacing will be done and advising such property owners that
no pavement cuts shall be permitted for three years after such resurfacing or
paving is completed except in cases of emergency.
(Ord. 917. Passed 5-8-75.)
   (e)    The provisions of this section do not apply to emergency excavations
by the Water or Sewer Department of the Village, but such Department shall be
charged for the cost of repairing any street so excavated.
(Ord. 559.  Passed 9-10-51.)
905.03  INSTALLATION OF CULVERTS.
   (a)    The installation of culverts along or across streets or alleys within
the corporation is hereby prohibited unless written approval is given by the
Street Committee of Council.
   (b)    No culverts shall be installed of a diameter of less than ten inches
or such greater diameter as shall be determined by the Street Committee based
on the volume of water to be handled. (Ord. 81-5. Passed 5-13-81.)
905.99  PENALTY.
   (a)    Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which no other
penalty is provided is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
   (b)    Whoever violates any provision of Section
905.02 shall be fined not more than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00).
(Ord. 917. Passed 5-8-75.)

909.01  MATERIAL FOR SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION.
   Any sidewalks abutting upon or adjacent to a public street or alley and
running generally parallel with such public street or alley shall be
constructed of concrete material.  The base of the sidewalk shall be
constructed of stone or gravel and shall be vibra tamped.  No sidewalk shall
hereafter be constructed or repaired by the use of asphalt, cement, concrete,
or other bituminous material.  This section shall not apply to sidewalks
located on private property and not abutting upon or adjacent to a public
street or alley and not running generally parallel to such public street or
alley.
(Ord. 2013-26.  Passed 1-22-14.)
909.02  SIDEWALK REPLACEMENT OR CONSTRUCTION.
   (a)   Definitions.  For the purpose of this chapter the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
      (1)   “Residential in nature” means a sidewalk not located in front of or
adjacent to a commercial establishment or other place where a group of ten or
more persons hold meetings or a place open to the public.
      (2)   “Sidewalk” means the specifications for replacement or new
construction of a sidewalk shall be those of a portland cement concrete
sidewalk of not less than four-inches thickness, (six inches at driveways),
utilizing at least six bags of concrete per cubic yard.
         (Ord. 87-5.  Passed 6-10-87.)
   (b)   Application for Partial Payment.  Any property owner or the agent of
any property owner who plans to replace or newly construct public sidewalks
upon property which he controls within the Village limits may make written
application to the Fiscal Officer or the Village Administrator of the Village
upon forms provided by the Village for partial payment by the Village of the
costs of such replacement of sidewalks.  Upon receipt of such application, the
Village Administrator shall make or cause to be made an inspection of the
sidewalk to be replaced, or the area upon which a new sidewalk is to be
constructed, and if upon inspection, the Village Administrator with approval of
the Village Service Committee and Council as a whole that it is in the public
interest that such replacement or construction be carried out, the Village
Administrator shall be authorized to commit the Village to pay between fifty
percent (50%) and seventy-five percent (75%) of the costs of sidewalk
replacement pursuant to this subsection.  The Village Administrator shall
recommend the amount to be paid by the Village and submit the recommendation to
Council for approval by a majority of the members of Council.  In determining
the amount to be paid by the Village the Village Administrator shall consider
the applicant’s age, earning abilities, current income (based upon Federal LMI
guidelines), health condition, and any other factor deemed relevant by the
Village Administrator.
   (c)   Check to Accompany Application.  The application for partial payment
by the Village for the replacement of new construction of sidewalks as set
forth in subsection (b) hereof shall be accompanied by a written estimate of
costs for the proposed replacement or construction from a legitimate and
reliable contractor who has replaced or constructed sidewalks as a part of this
business, along with a certified check or money order, payable to the
contractor representing the applicant’s share of the cost of replacement as
estimated by such contractor.  The Fiscal Officer shall hold the certified
check or money order until the work is completed in a satisfactory manner or as
otherwise provided herein.
(Ord. 09-2002.  Passed 7-24-02.)
   (d)   Time for Applications Submission; Priority.  Written applications as
provided in subsection(b) hereof, shall be submitted to the Fiscal Officer or
the Mayor no later than July 1, 1987, and on or before June 1, of each
succeeding year.  Applications will be handled by the Village in the priority
in which they are received.  The Mayor and Fiscal Officer shall discontinue
receiving applications once sufficient applications have been received and
approved by the Village to exhaust available funds.  Sidewalks residential in
nature shall be given priority for available funds over commercial sidewalks.
   (e)   New Application for Uncompleted Work.  If an application has been
approved and a deposit made, all work must be completed within 60 days of the
permit approval.  If the work is not completed within 60  days of application
approval, the application shall be null and void and of no further force and
effect and the applicant will be required to reapply for a new permit.
   (f)   Application Rejection; Appeals; Override of Decision.  If the
application for Village participation in replacement or construction of a
sidewalk as provided for in subsection(b) hereof is rejected by the Mayor and
Street Committee, the applicant may appeal the decision.  Such appeal shall be
to Council in writing.  Council shall give its decision on the appeal no later
than its second regularly scheduled meeting after Council’s receipt of the
appeal.  Such decision shall be based upon the concurrence of a majority of
Council and shall be transmitted to the applicant in writing.  If Council
sustains the decision to reject the application, the reasons for the rejection
shall be stated in Council’s written answer to the applicant.  Council shall
also have the power to override by a majority vote of the members of Council,
the decision to commit the Village to pay a portion of the replacement cost of
sidewalks and may establish what, if any, portion of the replacement cost shall
be borne by the Village. 
   (g)   Service of Notice.  The Chief of Police, any policeman, the Mayor or
Fiscal Officer may make service and receive return of notice provided for in
this chapter.
   (h)   Specifications; Exceptions.
      (1)   All sidewalks within the limits of the Village whether new or to be
replaced, shall be parallel to the center line of the street and shall slope
toward the curb with a slope of three-sixteenths of an inch and shall be not
less than five feet in width.  If it is determined by the Street Committee that
it would be in the best interests of those concerned, the sidewalk to be
replaced may be less than five feet.
      (2)   Where an existing sidewalk of a greater width than five feet is
being replaced, the new walk shall be of at least the same width as the one it
replaced.  If there is a grass strip between the curb and the sidewalk, the
grass strip shall have a slope toward the curb of at least one-half inch in
twelve inches.
      (3)   All sidewalks shall be concrete with a minimum thickness of four
inches under pedestrian traffic and six inches through driveways, utilizing at
least six bags of concrete per cubic yard.
      (4)   If trees exist within the proposed line of sidewalk construction or
replacement, they shall be protected by maintaining a twelve-inch clearance
from the edge of the tree to the edge of the sidewalk, the open area to be
filled with suitable soil or mulch.
      (5)   All sidewalks that adjoin curbs at crosswalks shall be installed
using curb ramps as shown on standard construction drawing BP-12 Ohio
Department of Transportation.
   (i)   Maximum Yearly Expenditure.  The amount of money expended by the
Village for the repair or replacement of sidewalks shall not exceed the sum of
seven thousand dollars ($7,000) in the year 1987, and shall not exceed the sum
of ten thousand dollars ($10,000) in the year 1988 or any succeeding year. 
(Ord. 87-5.  Passed 6-10-87.)
   (j)   Target Area.  The Village of Byesville shall have the right to
establish a target area for comprehensive sidewalk replacement.  The Village
shall consider the overall condition of sidewalks in the proposed target area
relative to public safety.  Village Council shall have the right to establish
partial payment schedules in target areas in appropriate amounts when the need
arises.
   (k)   No property owner shall be considered for participation in the
sidewalk replacement program described in this chapter when the property owner
has delinquencies due and owing to the Village for water or sewer service,
village income tax, or when the property owner is in violation of the Property
Maintenance Code of the Village of Byesville.
(Ord. 2013-26.  Passed 1-22-14.)
   (l)   Mandatory Repair.
      (1)   Each year the Village Administrator, with approval of the Village
Services Committee and Council as a whole may designate a particular area of
the Village for concentration for the sidewalk replacement program to replace
sidewalks that the Village Administrator has determined to be a nuisance,
unsafe, a danger to the health and welfare of the residents of the Village or
in violation of any section of the Codified Ordinances of the Village.  The
Village Administrator with approval of the Village Service Committee and
Council as a whole that it is in the public interest that such replacement or
construction be carried out, the Village Administrator shall be authorized to
commit the Village to pay between fifty percent (50%) and seventy-five percent
(75%) of the costs of sidewalk replacement pursuant to this subsection.  The
Village Administrator shall recommend the amount to be paid by the Village and
submit the recommendation to Council for approval by a majority of the members
of Council.  In determining the amount to be paid by the Village, the Village
Administrator shall consider the applicant’s age, earning abilities, current
income (based upon Federal LMI guidelines), health condition, and any other
factor deemed relevant by the Village Administrator.
      (2)   In the event property owner fails to reimburse the Village for
payment of the property owner’s share of the sidewalk replacement, the Village
shall be authorized to assess the cost to the property owner’s taxes by
certifying the delinquency to the office of the Guernsey County Auditor.
         (Ord. 09-2002.  Passed 7-24-02.)
909.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor.  Any violation shall constitute a separate offense on each
successive day continued.

913.01  CUTTING OR REMOVAL; PERMIT.
   (a)    No individual company or other party shall cut or remove any tree
located between the sidewalk and a curb in the Village, without first obtaining
a permit from Council.
   (b)    Such permit, shall be obtained by contacting the Fiscal Officer who
then shall relay the matter to the Street Committee for their review and
approval.
(Ord. 83-2. Passed 2-8-83.)
913.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor for the first offense. Any person who violates any provision of
this chapter as a second offense shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor of the
fourth degree. Any such violation shall constitute a separate offense on each
day the violation exists.
(Ord. 83-2. Passed 2-8-83.)

intergovernmental agreements in place as of the passage of this section.  (Ord.

937.02  WATER OR SEWER TAP INSPECTION; FEE.
   Anybody tapping directly or indirectly into the City water or sewer lines
must request an inspection and pay an inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00).
(Ord. 921.  Passed 7-14-75.)

941.01  DWELLING UNIT, MULTIPLE DWELLING UNIT DEFINED.
   (a)   For the purpose of this chapter “dwelling unit” means any room, group
of rooms, house trailer or other enclosure occupied or intended for occupancy
as separate living quarters by a family or other group of persons living
together or by persons living alone shall be classified as a dwelling unit. 
Each dwelling in a double house, in a row of connecting houses or in an
apartment shall be billed as a separate entity.  This shall not include hotels,
motels, hospitals, nursing homes, and sleeping rooms.  Sleeping rooms are
defined as rooms without separate kitchen or bathroom facilities.  In trailer
parks, dwelling units shall include each space for which water is available,
whether occupied or not.
   (b)   “Multiple dwelling unit”  means those units in which more than one
dwelling unit is served by one meter.  (Ord. 1003 . Passed 3-13-78.)
941.02  CONNECTIONS.
   (a)   Except in places where special permission to the contrary is granted
by the Village Administrator, no application for water shall be allowed until
the applicant can show that the property is to be supplied through a separate
and independent water service connection from the main line.
   (b)   Except in places where special permission to the contrary is granted
by the Village Administrator, no application for water shall be allowed until
the applicant can show that the property to be served is below 900 feet msl. 
(Ord. 2004-03.  Passed 3-24-04.)
941.03  WATER METERS.
   (a)   A separate water meter and “shut off” for measuring the consumption of
water shall be installed for each dwelling, store, institution, manufacturing
plant or place of business before water will be furnished to it.  The cost of
the water meter shall be paid by the property owner.  The user will also be
required to pay for all necessary repairs to the meter.  Change of ownership of
the user shall not require a new tap-in fee and the payment for a new meter. 
The Village reserves the right to inspect the meter at any reasonable time and
notify the owner of any repairs it may consider necessary to be made and make
the same.  Repair bills remaining unpaid shall be certified to the County
Auditor in the same manner as unpaid water bills.
(Ord. 2006-14.  Passed 6-28-06.)
   (b)    All property owners with a meter larger than one inch (1") shall be
subject to mandatory annual water meter testing by a company approved by the
Water  Superintendent or the Village Administrator.  Costs of the testing shall
be the responsibility of the property owner.
 
   (c)   The annual meter testing required under this Section shall commence in
the calendar year 2003.  Thereafter, such annual testing will be completed on
or before June 1st of each successive year.  A written report of the result of
the testing shall be submitted to the Water Superintendent. 
(Ord. 17-2002.  Passed 11-27-02.)
   (d)   Structures or premises that are serviced by an independent service
line whose primary use is for fire protection and/or for a fire suppression
system shall be equipped with a compound fire flow meter that is UL/FM rated
installed in the service line.  The meter shall be purchased from the Byesville
Village Water Department and shall conform to current specifications of the
Byesville Village Water Department.  Installation of said meter shall conform
to all current specifications of the Byesville Village Water Department.
(Ord. 2004-8.  Passed 10-13-04.)
941.04  RATES.
   (a)   The inside the corporation limit water rate shall be $4.70 per 1000
gallons of usage, the equivalent of .0047 per gallon.
   (b)   Consumer accounts using less than 3000 gallons per month shall be
charged a
minimum of $14.10 monthly.
   (c)   Consumer accounts located outside the corporation limits will incur
the inside rate plus an additional fifty percent (50%), except where other
intergovernmental agreements exist.
   (d)   Rates for industrial and commercial users conducting operations
outside the Village corporation limit that average over 1,000,000 gallons
monthly shall be calculated using the inside rate plus 15%.
   (e)   Effective January 1, 2019 and reoccurring through January 1, 2023, the
inside rate shall increase 1% annually.
   (f)   Water tap fees be amended as follows:
      (1)   3/4" Service $900.00
      (2)   1" Service $1,300.00
      (3)   2" Service $1,400.00
      (4)   All taps over two inches will be charged at a rate of one $1,200.00
per inch plus materials and meter.
      (5)   Tap on fees will include materials, a meter, and the necessary
labor to install service to the meter pit. Costs associated with street
openings and road boring will be additional.
      (6)   Outside the corporation tap fees shall be incurred at a rate of the
inside tap fee plus 50%.
      (7)   All tap fees must be paid prior to installation.
      (8)   It is the property owner's responsibility to maintain the location
of an existing tap.
   (g)   The foregoing charges are minimum charges and not maximum charges and
the Village Administrator reserves the right and is obligated to increase the
same at any time should the revenues of the water works system prove
insufficient to pay present and future operations and bonding indebtedness.
   (h)   A twenty-five dollar ($25.00) service charge each shut-off performed
and each turn-on performed due to non-payment of billing or request for shut-
off.  All other services will be charged for any services performed other than
normal duty hours.  The normal duty hours shall be established by the Village
Administrator.
   (i)   A $50.00 service charge will be charged for any service performed
anytime other than normal business yours. The normal business hours shall be
established by the Village Administrator.
   (j)   A water guarantee deposit of $100.00 shall be charged for the
following:
      (1)   New property owners who have not had water service established
within the Village.
      (2)   All tenants/renters whether water service has been established or
not.
   (k)   The water guarantee deposit is a non-interest bearing deposit.
Property owners' deposits shall be credited against current billing after 12
months or six consecutive billing cycles if all bills are paid by the due
date.  Tenants/renters/land contractors' deposits shall be held/applied to the
final billing. No final bill refunds of less than $1.00 shall be refunded.
(Ord. 2018-05.  Passed 4-25-18.)
941.05  UNPAID WATER BILLS. (REPEALED)
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
941.05 was repealed by Ordinance 2018-4.
941.06  DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE.
   Upon the consumer’s or owner’s desire for discontinuation of service, the
minimum billing charge shall continue until such time as the consumer or owner
notifies the office of the Village Administrator of the Village of such desire
of discontinuation at which time the Village shall shut off the service.  The
shutting off of the service by the consumer or owner does not constitute a work
order and does not release the consumer or owner, from the payment of the
minimum service charges of such service. 
(Ord. 17-2002.  Passed 11-27-02.)
941.07  LIABILITY OF OWNER AND LESSEE.
   The owner of private property which is served by the waterworks system by
pipes connected with the system to convey water thereto, shall as well as the
lessee of the premises, be liable to the Village for all water from the system
used upon the premises.
(Ord. 1003. Passed 3-13-78.)
941.08  MINIMUM BILLING FOR MULTIPLE DWELLING UNIT.
   The minimum billing for a multiple dwelling unit shall be the minimum
billing for a dwelling unit multiplied by the number of dwelling units.  If
water usage exceeds the minimum usage allowed for the number of dwelling units
in the multiple dwelling unit, the billing for excess water shall be calculated
at the regular rate.
(Ord. 1003.  Passed 3-13-78.)
941.09  NOTIFICATION OF MULTIPLE DWELLING UNITS.
   Owner’s of multiple dwelling units shall notify the Village Administrator of
the location of the multiple dwelling unit and the number of dwelling units
contained therein.  This notice shall be in writing and shall be given within
ninety days of the effective date of these water rates, or within thirty days
of acquisition of a multiple dwelling unit, whichever comes later.
(Ord. 17-2002.  Passed 11-27-02.)
941.10  TIME OF PAYMENT OF WATER BILLS.
   The water charges established in this Chapter are payable on a bi-monthly
basis payable on or before the 15th of the month. (Ord. 2005-17.  Passed 12-21-
05.)
941.11  WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM PERMITTED OUTSIDE VILLAGE LIMITS.
   (a)   The Village water distribution system may be extended outside the
corporation limits of the Village upon written approval of the Water
Superintendent and the Village Administrator.  Any person(s), firm or
corporation approved by the Village Administrator shall be allowed to install a
water tap pursuant to Village specifications.  The entire cost of the
extension, including labor to install said line, shall be borne solely by the
person(s), firm or corporation making the extension.  Tap fees will be waived
when taps are made at the time of the extension.  Water meters for the said
mentioned taps must be purchased from the Village.  Line extensions and taps
shall be made according to the current Standard Detail Drawings of the
Village.  Water line sizing will be determined by the Water Superintendent and
the Village Administrator.
   (b)   Persons wishing to tap on to an extended line, following the
completion of the extensions, will be required to pay for half of the original
cost of the line that fronts the property where said tap is being installed, as
well as the cost of the tap.  This cost can be calculated using the following
calculation:
(Original Cost of Line Extension/Total Footage *Property Frontage/0.5) +
Current Tap Fee = Cost to be paid by Person(s) tapping into an extended line.
   (c)   This cost will be collected for a period of ten years following any
line extension paid for by a third party in which the Village has in writing
assumed responsibility and upkeep of said water line following the one-year
maintenance agreement.  This fee minus half of the current tap cost will be
returned to the original developer(s) up to and including the original cost of
making the line extension(s).
   (d)   Approved Ohio Environmental Protection Agency plans must be obtained
prior to the installation of said water line.  The Village requires three sets
of Ohio Environmental Protection Agency approved plans be delivered to the
Water Superintendent prior to the installation of said waterline, as well as
three sets of as-built plans following completion of said waterline
installation.
   (e)   Any person(s) receiving service from the Village water distribution
system outside of the corporation limits of the Village of Byesville shall be
required to sign a pre-annexation agreement.  (Ord. 2004-03.  Passed 3-24-04.)
941.12  BACKFLOW PREVENTION.
   (a)   If, in the judgment of the Water Superintendent, an approved backflow
prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water system, the
Water Superintendent will give notice to the water consumer to install such an
approved device immediately.  The water consumer shall, at his own expense,
install such an approved device at a location and in a manner approved by the
Water Superintendent and shall have inspections and tests made of such approved
devices as required by the Water Superintendent.
   (b)   No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be
established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a
private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the regular public
water supply of Byesville may enter the supply or distributing system of the
municipality, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the
method of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved by the
Water Superintendent and by the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency.
   (c)   It shall be the duty of the Water Superintendent to cause surveys and
investigations to be made of industrial and other properties served by the
public water supply where actual or potential hazards to the public water
supply may exist.  Such surveys and investigations shall be made a matter of
public record and shall be repeated as often as the Water Superintendent shall
deem necessary.
   (d)   The Water Superintendent or his or its duly authorized representative
shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a
connection to the public water supply or distribution system of the Village for
the purpose of inspecting the piping system or systems thereof.  On demand the
owner, lessees or occupants of any property so served shall furnish to the
Water Superintendent any information which he may request regarding the piping
system or systems or water used on such property.  The refusal of such
information, when demanded, shall, within the discretion of the Water
Superintendent, be deemed evidence of the presence of improper connections as
provided in this section.
   (e)   The Water Superintendent is hereby authorized and directed to
discontinue, after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, the water service
to any property wherein any connection in violation of the provisions of this
section is known to exist, and to take such other precautionary measures as he
may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water
supply distribution mains.  Water service to such property shall not be
restored until such conditions shall have been eliminated or corrected in
compliance with the provisions of this section.  (Ord. 88-8.  Passed 7-13-88.)
941.13  WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM EXTENSION INSIDE VILLAGE LIMITS.
   (a)    The Village water distribution system may be extended inside the
corporation limits of the Village upon written approval of the Water
Superintendent and the Village Administrator.  Any person(s), firm or
corporation approved by the Village Administrator shall be allowed to install a
water tap pursuant to Village specifications.  The entire cost of the
extension, excluding labor to install said line, shall be borne solely by the
person(s), firm or corporation making the extension.  Tap fees will be waived
when taps are made at the time of the extension.  Water meters for the said
mentioned taps must be purchased from the Village.  Line extensions and taps
shall be made according to the current Standard Detail Drawings of the
Village.  Water line sizing will be determined by the Water Superintendent and
the Village Administrator.
   (b)   Persons wishing to tap on to an extended line, following the
completion of the extensions, will be required to pay for half of the original
cost of the line that fronts the property where said tap is being installed, as
well as the cost of the tap.  This cost can be calculated using the following
calculation:
(Original Cost of Line Extension/Total Footage *Property Frontage/0.5) +
Current Tap Fee = Cost to be paid by person(s) tapping into an extended line.
   (c)   This cost will be collected for a period of ten years following any
line extension paid for by a third party in which the Village has in writing
assumed responsibility and upkeep of said waterline following the one-year
maintenance agreement.  This fee minus half of the current tap cost will be
returned to the original developer(s) up to and including the original cost of
making the line extension(s).
   (d)    Approved Ohio Environmental Protection Agency plans must be obtained
prior to the installation of said waterline.  The Village requires three sets
of Ohio Environmental Protection Agency approved plans be delivered to the
Water Superintendent prior to the installation of said waterline, as well as
three sets of as-built plans following completion of said water line
installation.  (Ord. 2004-03.  Passed 3-24-04.)
 
941.14  SALE OF NON-POTABLE WATER.
   (a)   The Village authorizes the sale of non-potable water.
 
   (b)   “Non-Potable Water” is hereby defined as water that is unsuitable for
human consumption.
 
   (c)   The rate for the sale of non-potable water shall be $5.00 per 1,000
gallons.
(Ord. 2011-16.  Passed 12-21-11.)
941.15   SALE OF BULK POTABLE WATER.
   (a)   The Village of Byesville authorizes the sale of bulk potable water.
   (b)   “Bulk Potable Water” is hereby defined as water that is suitable for
human consumption and dispensed at an approved bulk water filling station.
   (c)   The rate for the sale of bulk potable water is ten dollars ($10.00)
per 1000 gallons.
   (d)   For bulk users that average over 50,000 gallons monthly the Village
Administrator may negotiate a separate contractual rate of not less than $5.00
per one thousand gallons and not more than $10.00 per one thousand gallons.
(Ord. 2013-25.  Passed 1-22-14.)
941.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any bylaw or regulation made by the Village Administrator
pursuant to the authority granted by Ohio R.C. 735.29 or any provision of this
chapter, shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 17-2002.  Passed 11-27-02.)
